title: WYLL Meaning: What It Means & How to Respond

steps.title: WYLL means â€œWhat You Look Like.â€
steps.content: WYLL means â€œWhat You Look Like.â€ WYLL is a common abbreviation sent over DM, used as shorthand for the question â€œWhat do you look like?â€ People typically send this message to people they donâ€™t know well (like a stranger or acquaintance), in hopes that theyâ€™ll get a selfie or picture of the person in response. [2] X Research source Since this question is pretty personal, youâ€™re more likely to see WYLL in your DMs rather than in a comment or reply. WYLL means the same thing across all digital platforms, like TikTok, Roblox, texting, and more.

steps.title: Ask a new online friend or acquaintance what they look like.
steps.content: Ask a new online friend or acquaintance what they look like. Maybe you made a new friend on Snapchat, or youâ€™ve been hitting it off with someone you met on TikTok. If youâ€™re really curious to know what they look like IRL, shoot a quick WYLL and see if they send you a picture. Donâ€™t be too disappointed if they refuse to send anything back, thoughâ€”some people might not be super comfy sending pics to people they donâ€™t know super well. [3] X Research source â€œWYLL? Iâ€™ve only ever seen pics of your cat in your Snap Story lmaoâ€ â€œTbh Iâ€™m so curious wyllâ€

steps.title: Poke fun at someone with â€œWYLLâ€ and an accompanying picture or GIF.
steps.content: Poke fun at someone with â€œWYLLâ€ and an accompanying picture or GIF. Use â€œWYLLâ€ at the start of your sentence to make fun of how someone is acting/reacting to something. Start off the message with â€œWYLLâ€¦â€ and then follow up with your silly quip, along with a picture or gif of how youâ€™re imagining them at that moment. [4] X Research source â€œWYLL trying to submit that essay before midnightâ€ [gif of Kermit the frog typing furiously] â€œWYLL in the Twitter replies rnâ€ [gif of kittens fighting]

steps.title: Share information about yourself if you feel comfortable doing so.
steps.content: Share information about yourself if you feel comfortable doing so. Think about how you feel about the person youâ€™re chatting with. Do you feel comfortable enough sharing something like a selfie with them? If youâ€™ve been sharing some fun vibes with this person (and they havenâ€™t triggered your â€œcreeperâ€ radar), it could be worth sending a quick selfie over. Itâ€™s completely fair to set boundaries as well, and let them know that you wonâ€™t send them any pics. Them: â€œWYLL?â€ You: [picture of yourself] Them: â€œwyllâ€ You: â€œLol I donâ€™t think weâ€™re quite there yetâ€ You can always use a Bitmoji sticker on Snapchat if you arenâ€™t quite ready to send an actual picture of yourself. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Choose not to respond if you feel uncomfortable.
steps.content: Choose not to respond if you feel uncomfortable. If youâ€™re chatting with a perfect stranger, a sudden â€œWYLLâ€ message can be pretty jarring, especially if itâ€™s sent to you right off the bat. Rememberâ€”thereâ€™s absolutely no obligation to respond to anyone who makes you feel uncomfortable, and no one is automatically entitled to any pictures of you. Pro tip: Your safety and well-being always come first, especially when youâ€™re online. If someone ever makes you uncomfortable, donâ€™t be afraid to block and report their account. If youâ€™re texting someone who makes you feel weird, block their number .

steps.title: Send a playful response back if someone teases you.
steps.content: Send a playful response back if someone teases you. Let your friend know what you think about the comparison theyâ€™ve just madeâ€”if all else fails, a quick â€œLOLâ€ or â€œhahahaâ€ can do the trick. If youâ€™d like, feel free to throw out an Uno reverse card by sending your own â€œWYLLâ€ message back at them, making fun of them in an equally goofy way. Them: â€œWYLL waiting for Matt to text you backâ€ [gif of a person sweating] You: â€œSTOP I feel so called out rn ğŸ˜­â€ Them: â€œWYLL waiting for the Jags to make it to the Super Bowlâ€ [picture of a skeleton] You: â€œWYLL expecting the Ravens to have a good seasonâ€ [gif of person putting on clown makeup]

steps.title: Stay on top of new texting slang with these common acronyms.
steps.content: Stay on top of new texting slang with these common acronyms. Learn these popular slang terms to stay in the know and keep your texts looking like English instead of gibberish: ISK : A typo for IDK (â€œI donâ€™t knowâ€) or â€œI should knowâ€ IDM : â€œI donâ€™t mindâ€ MCM : â€œMan crush Mondayâ€ WCW : â€œWoman crush Wednesdayâ€ MBN : â€œMust be niceâ€ FFF : â€œFollow for followâ€ PMO : â€œPut me onâ€ (introduce to someone or something) OOMF : â€œOne of my followersâ€ or â€œone of my friendsâ€ OMW â€™â€™: â€œOn my wayâ€
